text: Correspondence Joshua S. Gans, University of Toronto and NBER, Canada. Email: joshua.gans@gmail.com

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Abstract Economists have often viewed the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) as a standard process innovation where we expect that efficiency will drive adoption in competitive markets. This paper models AI based on recent advances in machine learning that allow firms to engage in bet- ter prediction. Focusing on prediction of demand, it is demonstrated that AI adoption is a complement to vari- able inputs whose levels are altered directly by predictions and whose use is economized by them (that is, labour). It is shown that in a competitive market, this increases the short-run elasticity of supply and may or may not increase average equilibrium prices. Generically, there are externalities in adoption, with this reducing the profits of non-adoptees when variable inputs are important, and increasing them otherwise. Thus AI does not operate as a standard process innovation, and its adoption may confer positive externalities on non-adopting firms. In the long run, AI adoption is shown to lower prices generally and raise consumer surplus in competitive markets.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: 1 INTRODUCTION

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: As a general rule, technologies that improve the efficiency of production tend to interact with competitive effects to encourage their adoption. For instance, a process innovation that lowers marginal costs or raises factor productivity will be adopted by competitive firms in part because the profits of non-adoptees fall as others adopt; that is, adoptees create negative external effects on non-adoptees. As more firms adopt, prices fall, as do the profits of those that do not adopt. This paper demonstrates that this general rule does not apply generally to artificial intelligence (AI). Recent research has viewed AI as equivalent to task automation and hence a standard process innovation.1 The tendency to equate AI adoption with automation does, however, mask the fact that recent advances in AI are all advances in machine learning that permits lower cost and/or better quality predictions.2 Such advances in prediction can enable more opportunities for automation by machines—by combining that prediction with machine actions such as might arise for self-driving vehicles—but, at the same time, this has caused some to suggest that AI advances could be directed or redirected to augment rather than replace human labour (Markoff 2016; Acemoglu and Restrepo 2020b; Brynjolfsson 2022).

text: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE ADOPTION

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: . Economica

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: In this paper, I take seriously the notion that AI is prediction in order to properly character- ize the type of technological change that it represents, and what would guide its adoption in a competitive market. The focus here is on the prediction of demand (a) as an important task in which firms engage, and (b) that allows for a greater contrast with other models of AI adoption in economics that focus on capital to labour substitution of work tasks.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: What demand predictions do is allow firms to match decisions, such as output and employ- ment, with the predicted state. Thus while a firm without such predictions may make decisions based on the average external state, AI prediction allows those decisions to vary. So while out- put might be relatively stable when there is no prediction, the availability of a prediction may cause firms to increase or reduce output accordingly. While this represents an improvement in efficiency, it will be shown here that because some of the efficiency gain comes from reducing output, it may be that the external effect of AI adoption on other firms is positive rather than negative. Rather than adoption spurring others to adopt, the opposite may be the case, with the returns to adoption falling.3

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: To model this, I focus here on the canonical environment where competitive firms face uncer- tainty regarding market demand for their products. My starting point is an observation by Nelson (1961) that, when facing uncertainty about demand, a firm’s behaviour depends critically on how well it can make predictions regarding that demand. The value of such predictions is that the firm can make short-run adjustments to output that, when marginal costs are rising, allow it to match more efficiently output choices to realized market prices. This has important implications for how we characterize AI as a technological advance. In particular, at its heart, AI prediction is useful only insofar as it can change decisions. In the context of a price-taking firm, the relevant decisions involve the employment of factors of production to generate output. If the predictions are useful in the short run, then we can refine the relevant decisions even further to focus on fac- tor employment decisions themselves made in the short run. As will be shown, this implies that fundamentally, AI involves augmenting the productivity of factors that are variable in the short run. That is, in this way AI augments the productivity of variable rather than fixed inputs. In the case of many firms, this means that they augment labour directly rather than capital, which is typically fixed in the short run.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Nelson (1961) explores the value of adopting predictions by such firms but does not embed it in an equilibrium model of competitive market outcomes. He therefore does not examine the interaction between the profits of adopters and non-adopters.4 Here, I provide that analysis while abstracting away from some of the imperfections in predictive accuracy that were the focus of the older literature (see, in particular, Pashigian 1974). Several results emerge. First, the above intuition that AI is labour augmenting is confirmed. Second, the value of AI to a firm comes from the variance in market prices caused by variation in demand. Third, as more firms adopt AI, this changes the variance in market prices—reducing it—as those firms adjust short-term output in a way that mitigates price variability. Fourth, AI adoption can have positive or negative external effects on the profits of firms that do not adopt AI. This may spur or diminish the diffusion of AI in a competitive market. Fifth, AI adoption can, in some cases, have a negative impact on consumer surplus even in a competitive market. Sixth, when firms interact in factor markets (such as labour) prior to making output decisions, prices in those markets can signal prediction outcomes. This informational spillover further reduces the incentives to adopt AI. Finally, in the long run, when capital can adjust, market prices are on average lower, and quantity is on average higher, with AI adoption in the industry than without it.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: In what follows, I begin with a short-run analysis before turning to interactions between product and factor markets, and then to a long-run treatment. The main conclusion reached is that what AI does matters for how it enters into the production function of firms, and that in competitive markets, how this translates into pricing and welfare outcomes can be subtle. Importantly, there are reasons to suppose that competitive forces will not necessarily spur AI adoption.

text: There is a continuum of firms i ∈ [0, 1] in a market. Firms have an identical production function f (Li, Ki) that is non-decreasing and convex in the quantity of labour Li and capital Ki. The wage rate is w, with labour supply perfectly elastic to the industry. The labour choice is variable in the short run. In the long run, capital can be altered at a rental rate r per unit of capital chosen. Initially, as factor prices are not the focus, w is set equal to 1 for expositional simplicity.

text: It is critical to note here that the adoption of AI is enhancing the productivity that the firm is able to generate from employing labour. In this respect, it is labour-augmenting technologi- cal change. However, because it augments labour as a factor that can be adjusted to maximize productivity, this does not necessarily translate into a high quantity of labour employed, on average.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: If the rate at which marginal productivity decreases with output itself falls with output, then a firm adopting AI will supply a higher output on average than one without AI. Because the outputs of firms adopting AI and those not adopting AI are substitutes in demand, an expansion in the average output of firms adopting AI will contract the output of other firms. However, in equilibrium, the former effect outweighs the latter, resulting in higher expected quantity and lower expected prices.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: The next result of interest is with regard to the variance of observed market prices when k firms adopt AI. text: Proposition 2. When k > 0, the variance of ̂P(𝜃) is less than the variance of Φ(𝜃).

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Proof. The proof follows trivially from the fact that 𝜃 is the intercept of linear market (inverse) demand. Thus when supply is inelastic (i.e. as it is when k = 0), the variance of 𝜃 and ̂P(𝜃) are equal, implying that when supply is elastic, the variance of ̂P(𝜃) falls. ▪

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Proposition 2 implies that the expected profit for firms adopting AI will be falling in k. As more firms adopt AI, the lower is the variance in prices and the lower are the benefits that can be achieved by matching firm output to price. The adoption decision, however, will be guided by the effect that AI adoption has, if any, on the expected profits of firms that do not adopt AI. The following example with 𝛼 = 1 shows that, as implied by Proposition 1, the profits of non-adoptees 2 are unchanged as other firms adopt AI because expected market price is unchanged.

text: 3 LABOUR MARKET INTERACTIONS

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: The analysis thus far takes the wage rate w, as exogenous to the firms in the industry. Here, this assumption is relaxed, and the wage rate is determined by equilibrium in the labour mar- ket. (The wage rate was also set equal to 1, but here it is reintroduced as a variable). If no firms adopt AI, then their demand curve for labour is stable and would not cause variation in the real- ized wages in the labour market. However, if a sufficient number of firms adopt AI, then their demand curves will be state-dependent. Thus as their output—and hence employment—choices are made after they receive a prediction of demand, this may impact on realized wages. In this situation, non-adoptees, if they know the number of firms that have adopted AI, may be able to infer 𝜃 from realized wages that they themselves must pay prior to production. Thus, in a manner reminiscent of Grossman and Stiglitz (1980), firms adopting AI are, by their actions, impacting upon observed price outcomes that provide an alternative signal to others of AI demand predictions that they have received. The difference here is that information is conveyed through prices not through single market asset trades but through vertical market effects; this was explored previously by Gibbons et al. (2012), but here arises in a model not based on incomplete contracts.8

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: In contrast to the assumption thus far that labour was perfectly elastically supplied to the industry, here it is supposed that in the short run, the total supply of labour in the economy is fixed at ̃L. However, similarly to assumptions made by Gibbons et al. (2012), at any given time, that total supply is unknown and ̃L ∼ U[L, L]. No firm observes ̃L. This uncertain supply implies that the wage in the labour market is not solely determined by the demand of firms in the industry.

text: Thus when k > 0, the equilibrium wage potentially conveys information regarding 𝜃 with ̂w non-decreasing in 𝜃. As ̃L is never observed, it is not necessarily possible for firms to infer 𝜃 from the realized wage. Nonetheless, as k rises, the signal that can be extracted from wages may become more precise. This will mean that firms that do not adopt AI may receive some of the benefits from AI indirectly from those that have adopted it and incurred c. Therefore this pos- itive externality from AI adoption means that an outcome similar to Proposition 3 arises, and from the perspective of producer surplus, too few firms adopt AI. Indeed, when k = 1, the wage becomes

text: Note that if ̃L = L, then the lowest equilibrium wage consistent with 𝜃 = 1 is ̂w(1, L). Thus if ̂w > ̂w(1, L), then this implies that 𝜃 cannot be 1. At the other extreme, if ̃L = L, then the high- est equilibrium wage consistent with 𝜃 = 2 is ̂w(2, L). Thus if ̂w < ̂w(2, L), then this implies that 𝜃 cannot be 2. If, however, ̂w ∈ [̂w(2, L), ̂w(1, L)], then because ̂w is continuous and strictly decreas- ing in ̃L, any realized wage in this range can be generated by two possible demand curves, one associated with each value of 𝜃. Thus with probability 𝜌, 𝜃 = 1, and with probability 1 − 𝜌, 𝜃 = 2, and the wage reveals no new information to a non-adopting firm (i.e. their posterior distribution remains identical to their prior).

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: It is easy to show that this is greater than 0 and is increasing in k; that is, as more firms adopt, the probability that a clear signal is generated by wage outcomes is higher. Note that as k → 1, this ∕4(L − L). Thus adoptions always generate a positive probability becomes 3 signal, and if L∕L ≥ (4 − 3𝜌)∕ (12(1 − 𝜌) + 4), then that probability is equal to 1 before everyone adopts.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: The example shows that AI adoption sometimes provides a perfect signal of product market demand while at other times it provides no signal at all. The signal is provided when labour avail- ability outcomes are extreme. For instance, if there is low labour availability but wages are very high, then this is a signal that demand must also be relatively high. By contrast, if wages are low, then this might indicate that either demand is low or that there is more labour available. As firms do not observe labour availability, the signal is muted. While the example provides a stark con- trast between no signal and a perfect signal through wage rates, in reality, there will be imperfect signals. The important conclusion, however, is that the precision of the signals will rise as more firms are known to have adopted AI. Thus, separate from any price effect on non-adopting firms from AI adoption, there is a potential signalling effect through factor markets that reduces the marginal return to adopting AI as others adopt.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: 4 LONG-RUN ANALYSIS

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: The short-run analysis shows how the adoption of AI prediction of demand allows firms in a competitive market to adjust the quantity of their variable input, labour, to match the forecast level of demand. As noted, while the returns to AI adoption vary with the degree of adoption in the market, using AI increases the expected profits of firms in the short run. Thus it is natural to examine what happens in the long run.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: It is assumed that the AI prediction of 𝜃 is sufficient to generate a short-run prediction only. Thus only inputs variable in the short run can be adjusted in response to that prediction. Inputs, such as capital, that vary only in the long run, will therefore adjust only to the extent that these impact on expected short-run profits.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: To begin, when capital is fixed at Ki in the short run, for a firm without AI, its labour choice, resulting output and expected profit are

text: Let ̂Kk be the long-run equilibrium level of capital in the industry, given k. By Proposition 1, recall that for a fixed level of capital, E[̂P|k = 1, ̂Kk] < (≥) E[̂P|k = 0, ̂Kk] if 𝛼 > (≤) 1 . Note also that ∫ ̂P(𝜃|k = 1, ̂Kk)1∕(1−𝛼) dΦ(𝜃) ≥ E[̂P|k = 1, ̂Kk] by Jensen’s inequality. Thus the following result can be demonstrated.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Proposition 4. The aggregate amount of capital ̂K is higher when AI is adopted in the industry if 𝛼 ≤ 1 2

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Proof. First, note that E[̂P|k = 0, ̂K0] = ∫ ̂P(𝜃|k = 1, ̂K1)1∕(1−𝛼) dΦ(𝜃) > E[̂P|k = 1, ̂K1], proving , then E[̂P|k = 1, ̂K0] ≥ E[̂P|k = 0, ̂K0], which the second part of the proposition. Second, if 𝛼 ≤ 1 2 implies that ̂K1 > ̂K0. ▪

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: This shows that in the long run, the availability and adoption of AI leads to lower expected prices and higher expected output in the industry. However, we can unambiguously predict what happens to the aggregate amount of capital only if 𝛼, the labour share, is less than 1 − 𝛼, the capital share. Otherwise, it is possible that the aggregate level of capital could contract as AI is adopted. This is because when 𝛼 > 1 , it is possible that AI leads to lower levels of labour used 2 on average, and since these are complements with capital, this can cause capital utilized to fall. If capital and labour were substitutes in firm production, then these comparative static results would be reversed while, by the Le Chatelier Principle (Milgrom and Roberts 1996), the result remains that labour adjusts more in the long run—and hence expected price falls—following AI adoption than in the short run.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: 5 CONCLUSION

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: The tendency in the economic analysis of AI has been to equate AI adoption with automa- tion. While there are applications of AI that are embodied in capital, AI is fundamentally an improvement in prediction technology, and therefore its first-order impacts will be to improve decision-making under uncertainty. When considering, therefore, the impact of its adoption of different classes of factors of production, AI adoption (say as measured by the employment of people with AI skills) will be a complement to inputs that are more variable in the short run.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE ADOPTION

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: Economica

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: AI prediction allows those inputs to be chosen to better respond to changes in variables, and hence increases their efficiency on average. If such variable inputs are in terms of labour and its employment, then AI adoption will be primarily labour augmenting.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: This paper has examined AI adoption from this perspective in a competitive market. Even here, the adoption of AI has external effects on other firms. While most efficiency-enhancing innovations would involve adoption that reduced the profits of competing firms, here it is possi- ble that AI adoption could increase the profits of competing firms. This may, in turn, limit the adoption of AI across such markets. It is shown that this arises, however, when variable inputs impacted on by AI are a smaller share of total inputs used by the firm. The broader the impact of AI within a firm, the stronger the incentives to adopt, and these will be driven by competition. This suggests that researchers will need to be careful in measuring the adoption and impact of AI in such markets.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: There are many other issues that can be explored regarding the adoption of AI. One such avenue is to consider AI adoption by firms with market power—that is, who do not take market prices as given. This is explored by Gans (2022), who finds that the value of AI adop- tion differs depending on whether it is informing pricing, output choices or both. Another avenue might explore AI adoption beyond the prediction of demand. For instance, AI might be used to help firms to predict supply conditions and consequent fluctuations in factor pric- ing. While in some cases AI adoption drivers similar to those identified here for demand prediction may arise, AI may impact critically on contracts within supply chains (Agrawal et al. 2018).

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: More critically, there are empirical implications for AI adoption that can be derived from the results here. While current empirical analyses have focused on firm characteristics (in par- ticular, size) and how these drive AI adoption (see Goldfarb et al. 2020; Zolas et al. 2021; Alekseeva et al. 2021), the results here suggest that inter-firm interactions in competitive mar- kets may play a role. In particular, depending on the labour (or more generally variable factor) share in production in the industry, adoption by some firms may actually diminish adoption by others. This suggests that in more competitive markets, inter-firm effects may be important empirically.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: ACK NOWLED G ME NTS Thanks to Daron Acemoglu, Avi Goldfarb and Richard Holden for helpful discussions. All errors remain my own.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: NOTES 1 Recent work on the impact of AI has classified such advances as involving primarily increased automation. For instance, Acemoglu and Restrepo (2018) view production functions as the aggregate outcome from the performance of a num- ber of tasks. They distinguish technological change that augments labour productivity in a task directly from that which allows capital to replace labour in a task or augments capital productivity in a task. They show that ‘the impli- cations of automation and AI are generally very different from those of labor-augmenting advances’ (Acemoglu and Restrepo 2018, p. 212). This framework has guided much of the empirical work in trying to analyse and forecast the potential effect of AI on jobs and productivity. See, for example, Brynjolfsson and Mitchell (2017), Felten et al. (2018, 2021), Susskind (2020), Das et al. (2020), Acemoglu and Restrepo (2020a, 2021), Acemoglu et al. (2020) and Autor et al. (2022).

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: 2 From a statistical perspective, all machine learning approaches, including deep learning, reinforcement learning and general adversarial models, produce statistical predictions (see Igami 2020; Mullainathan and Spiess 2017; Agrawal et al. 2018, 2019a,b). This includes recent general language models like GPT-3 and generative models such as Dall-E and Stable Diffusion. The latter, for example, offers artistic representations that someone enter- ing a prompt would predict to see. This paper focuses on a more standard predictive task—predicting firm demand.

metadata.filename: Artificial intelligence adoption in a competitive market.pdf

text: 3 Canton (1982) argues that firms with market power would have an incentive to limit the flow of public information to others. Here, however, the information gathered by firms is not public.

text: 5 In a subsequent section, firms choose their long-run level of capital. 6 Baron (1970) considers the same environment as Nelson (1961) but where firms may be risk-averse. In general, the more risk-averse a firm is, the more they would prefer to adopt AI. Thus by focusing on the risk-neutral case, this paper abstracts away from risk preferences as a motivating factor for AI adoption.

(2012) are interested in a distinct set of research questions that arise in the context of firm boundaries under incomplete contracting, and whether otherwise similar firms might choose distinct organizational structures in equilibrium.
